title: Wireless FW Test Engineer
summary: The Wireless Connectivity Silicon team is looking for wireless FW test engineers to help ensure the quality of the innovative wireless silicon for application in Apple’s products!
description:
-  Collaborate with FW, Radio, MAC, and Systems engineering teams to develop a FW test plan to ensure the stability, reliability, function correctness, and performance of Apple’s wireless silicon FW and products.
-  Develop test infrastructure, and continuous integration flow for pre-silicon development and post-silicon validation, system integration, and debugging. Including precheck-in, nightly/weekly/release regression test.
-  Work on test plan development, manual and automatic test setup/scripts, publish test reports, collect test logs, first screen of test failure/debug.
-  Build pre-silicon, and post-silicon reference board test setups, as well as production specific test setups.
-  Develop FW test cases and test methodologies.
-  Design and Develop innovative ideas that address automation and execution problems.
-  Support development in debugging and reproducing issues, work with system QA on bug reproduction, log/statistic collection, run debug tests with debug FW build, etc.
-  Build test result dashboards, and support bug triage meetings.
key_qualifications:
3+ years proven experience as a Silicon firmware test engineer.
Experience with the development and execution of automated test and continuous integration frameworks.
Experience in FW/SW white box testing including test plan design, implementation, documentation, and maintenance.
Proficient in scripting and debugging in any of the following: Python, Perl, TCL, C++, or equivalent.
Strong problem solving and debugging skills: analyze and investigate test failures, errors, build issues, and be able to accurately drive issues to completion.
Thrive in a collaborative environment and be comfortable working with multi-functional team.
Excellent oral and written communication skills.
Understanding of embedded SW fundamentals and low-level hardware interfaces.
Understanding of wireless protocol, systems/MAC/PHY, and WiFi/BT Functional or Performance or Stability Testing.
